content: If there are no objections, I'd like to add cover art to this puzzle.

Two points from Notes:
* Each given word must have a distinctive prefix from the prefixes of the other given words.
* A prefix cannot be used by two different words.

Test 5:
verbose
verb
verbose
verb
verbose

Solution:
verbo
verb
verbo
verb
verbo

And it was approved by 3 different people. Currently this puzzle cannot be solved at all if you want to follow the description.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I think this puzzle is good enough and it's ready to go.

i could not focus on the contribution this week, you know, job. anyway...
i just added the keyword completion as suggested by one comment, and also found a strict definition of prefix just for the sake of it.
there is always place for improvement, but i am happy with the content of this contribution and with a decent amount of upvotes for a first contribution. at the time writing this comment, already 2 approvals, i.e. one last approval needed in the next 23 staying days.
clearly, comments from community have helped me a lot to enhance the contribution and showed me that a same goal can be understood in different ways.
thanks again.
I just finished it and I loved it ! Thanks !

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I think its an interesting problem.
I changed the constraints from N <= 20 to N <= 200
Accidentally removed my approval. Did not know, that this happens, if I klick again on the approved ;)

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I like it

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I like it

as indicated in first comment, this is my first contribution. i was not quite sure what will happen after the 30-day WIP. and that became a new 30-day approbation. so, that gives me 30 days more to improve it. i could then answer to some questions i thought i will never have time:
* same word in the given list
* stress test, only 200 words as the ouput seems to have a char limit
*  replaced the recursive solution by an iterative one to pass the stress test
* each word should really have a prefix. i added a rule to avoid the starvation raised by some.

With the current wording, I disagree with the last two sets: e.g. for the {A,AA} set, string "A" is not a unique prefix for either of them. (as a matter of fact, I'd consider string A not to have a unique prefix within the set)

IMHO, better explicitly state "each string has a unique prefix" (which makes the "each word is unique" note redundant) and remove/replace those cases.
I hope you received enough feedback from the community to improve your contribution. Once you have made the necessary updates, publish your contribution!

Nice one.
Something in the Medium difficulty range with couple of Tests that will TLE with BruteForce would also be good.  Plus, you can throw in other ASCII into the mix.

I REALLY enjoyed this one. It forced me to use a function, rather than just continual logic. I have 3 loops used,
i take each word (loop 1), 
then expand the letters of it(loop 2). (adding a beginning symbol to prevent false positives) 
finally i take a function (with an internal loop) and check if the current prefix at it's current expansion, is in the rest of the words. Probably horrible for optimization, so that would be neat to have a true long test. Like others have said.

What could really break this is if each word has a similar word 200 words down.
Meaning like "find" is the first word, and word 200 is "fine"
then "mild" is the second word and "mildew" is the 201st word etc... because this forces my loops to not break for a long time.

In your testcase with words containing all the same letters, I have the feeling that the right output should only contain the longest word since it's the only unique prefix among all the words. Please correct me if I'm wrong.
I like this puzzle a lot, maybe a stress test could make it more challenging.
It's the best

Hello,
Nice one :)
What would you expect as behavior in case you have twice the same word in input?
Or do we consider we get only different words in input?
Nice!
It was fun !
Nice problem.
Well written, good job!

Each validator must differ from the corresponding test; changing the order of the inputs doesn't make the test case different enough to prevent hardcoded solutions.

I don't think this is anywhere close to "Medium" difficulty; I would change it to "Easy", or make this a Clash of Code instead of a Classic Puzzle.
if  needed, i can add some comments in code solution. reading it one more time, i can see some perl memes.

please, note the following points:
* this is my first contribution, so of course i am ready to do many modifications from given advices.
* i wanted to learn how to make a contribution, but also i wanted to find some ways to attract some perl folks. One way is to migrate one puzzle from the perl weekly challenge into the codingame training challenge. first, i called for advices from different people in the perl community and from codingame as well to know if this approach was correct and accepted. then, i hope that, like perl folks know well the perl weekly challenge, they will be curious to see how a known puzzle can be handled in the codingame platform. finally, like they will know more about codingame, i would believe that they will participate to the fall challenge 2020 coming soon (I already made a call there: https://www.reddit.com/r/perl/comments/i4ybpj/game_code_challenge).

i updated the validators.
for the difficulty/type, i will wait for more feedback.
thx.
hi, thx for feedback. i did not think about stress tests. i guess that for such test, i will need to create a very long list of words with very long names: like a list of mega molecules. :)
thanks for warm words! :)
thanks. appreciated.
cool! happy that you got some fun!
thanks.

hi, thanks for encouraging feedback.

about given same word, this is a good question. shamely, i did not think about it, even though i know that the command line parsers accept that case (like -v -v -v, or --list one --list two --list three etc.).
no tester or validator checks that case.  like i am close to the deadline, i will just add a note in the goal indicating that word given several times is not in scope. that could be a next contribution with more to handle, like the output of a help/usage/man message.
thanks. i got red-shy reading this comment. :)

hi, you are right. the first sentence in the goal lets some void for different meanings. i added some notes to fill this void and indicate which way to go (each word must have a prefix, and if one word is under starvation, then the rule is to to set the prefix with the word itself). I hope it should be fine.

hi, thanks for detailed explanation.
i added a stress test and a stress validator. i could not put more than 200 words though. the output seems to have a max of characters.

thanks for feedback.
worldwide prefixes. i forgot that one in my last update. i wll try to find some time to add an extra test.

Hi, thanks for your time on this contribution. it took me some time to fully understand your feedback. like you were not the first one to raise that issue, i searched for more information to disambiguate the wording.
That brought me to maybe change the title and use expression like "distinctive prefix-based shortcuts". I was afraid that people think that I tried to post the same contribution with new words. So i preferred to add more detailed notes.
Many thanks.

i have faced the same pattern several times. :)
click, click, click witout thinking, and then another path than expected one...

really good catch.
double thanks.
Thx. I spent much more time than expected on it, but it is worth with all the great feedbacks.
thanks for final step. :)

i am puzzled by your comment. what is the purpose? to share an information with an expected answer/action or to show that you have the Truth? maybe both? how should we feel? relief that you enlightened us with your unvaluable knwoledge, and in the same time, ashamed for the rest of our life to be so less good than you? then, do you reach for a feedback from poor people like us, or did you just want to show your excellence, ô Lord? anyway...

natural languages are everything, except perfect. when there is a difference of interpretation, then communication and collaboration are the keys. being rude is too easy...

during the 6 weeks of review, i have added notes to disambiguate, based on people's feedback. paradoxically, longer they become, more ambiguous they can become.
i will add anew note to clarify the meaning of word in the context of the notes.

It's not against you. The only way to learn is try and sometimes fail. That's why there is a long time for contributions to be accepted and refined. But the fact that 3 people approved it and none of them noticed that (at the time) half of the constraints were not satisfied in one test/validator pair is horrific. I can clearly see that you responded to all comments and made a lot of changes.

Unfortunately the added statement is also not satisfied by the last test/validator pair:
"If a word shares all its prefixes with the other different words, then, to avoid starvation, its prefix will be itself, and all its prefixes cannot be used by other words."
Example: "verbose" shares all it's prefixes with the other occurances of the same word and therefor by this note it's prefix should be "verbose".

Unfortunately I don't speak Perl, so I cannot tell you where the problem is in your solution regarding this test case but based on what I think you do this:
1. sort the list of words (completely agree)
2. for each of the words that are not the last one.
  a) compare each prefix of the word with the next in list until it matches
  b) store said prefic + 1 char in an array
3. look up prefixes for the original order of words
But yet again, this is purely speculation.

Either way for Test 5 you have multiple occurances of "verb" and "verbose" so any consistent prefix searching should return either "v/verbo" (minimal match) or "verb/verbose" (maximal match),

If I'm right what you are missing is that you have to compare for not just the next word's prefixes but for the previous word's prefixes as well.

For all it's worth I think you should just delete the last test-validator pair as it adds only to the confusion. You can also clean up the complications regarding this case from the notes and make it a nice easy puzzle.

thanks for the detailed answer.
i will read it more carefully after the fall challenge. not trying to snob you. english is not my native language, i need time to compile it.

Renaming is totally fine. We can tell apart really new contributions easily from votes and number of comments.

(the 30 days limit is more of an anti-clutter measure than a real hurry-up timer. don't worry too much about it)
right, number of comments show it. i got a bit lost these last days to get the new ones. :)

I'm not sure how you can stress test it anymore, but my triple loop works. I do have breaks and such. Anyhow my very poor optimized test works - this is due to my limited ability. I was able to reduce a loop in my previous answer, here's a triple loop answer I wrote (python 3):

n = int(input())
words=[]
for i in range(n): words.append(input())
wordset = set(words)
for i in words:
    test=""
    for j in i:
        test+=j
        if test == i: print(test); break
        counter=0
        for k in wordset:
            if "@" + test in "@" + k: counter+=1
            if counter>1:break
        if counter==1: print(test); break

I wonder if 2 loops is possible.

I ran time measurements, and the worst one was .05 seconds or 1/20th of a second. These have 2 second time limits I believe. So my code is way beyond fast enough.

your code is fine. abit  longer than suggested soltuin, but each of your lines is way lighter, and many people prefer simple statements.

in many trainings, you will face the same pattern when reading input. you can make it one liner, something like:
`words = [ input() for _ in range(int(input())) ]`

the suggested code has also 3 loops, execpt that the 3rd one is not nested in the 2d one which does all its job first.
It's exactly like tab completion in reverse. :)
